comments.commentBody: The outcry is great.  There's an authentic forum for more intellectual conversations about where and how these problems (Trump) happen.  The outcry helped push Obama into 8 years as POTUS.  My skepticism about these sorts of things lies in the (un)reliability of statistical certainties and the uncouth behaviors stemming from the outdated DNA/lifestyle that is bottle-necking a large proportion of the populace in America.  And, if America is anything these days, it's the land of entitlement, where the worst expect the most, and the best expect it too, only more effectively.  Trump is what we deserve, and even if he doesn't get the presidency, our flirtations with annihilation are so egregious these days, it's only a matter of time before some other hideous reality comes up to bite us.

Of course she's telling us what we can and can't watch. By criticizing NBC for putting Trump on the show I think we can assume it's her belief that Fallon should not have had Trump as a guest. If Ms. Bee had her way Trump would not have been on the show and then those who want to watch him would not have been able to, simple as that.

By it's very definition being a liberal means open to new viewpoints. Today's progressives have forgotten that, if they don't like it I can't either.

She's full of herself and she's not very funny, let's see how long she lasts. Wilmore is gone, Noah's ratings are slumping. It seems that it all really was John Stewart. You can bet Stewart would have had Trump on.
You have an unusual definition of mild.

My Dear Mr/Ms Keane ... Many thanks for the correction and my apologies for not being a native born English speaker, but also I would have reflexively expected NYT commentators, of all people, to display a modicum of understanding for the foreign born citizens among us ... Now the main point. Is Samantha Bee criticizing Fallon's genial demeanor with Trump or is she saying that Fallon shouldn't have had Trump on the show at all? I would call the second alternative, if correct, a censuring of the public's right to view, evaluate, and judge the individual in question.

interesting confluence- there's half of a podcast from revisionist history (Malcolm Gladwell) devoted to the history of this song (and to an Elvis Costello song). http://revisionisthistory.com/episodes/07-hallelujah
performed that is...
Dan88, you need to broaden your concept of satire. You might also consider that Cohen is speaking in golden-hued retrospect about what may be his most popular and lucrative composition.
Jeff Buckley set the standard (even Cohen admits it).  Anyone else who tries only shows how much the pale in comparison to Buckley.

Agree, but to be fair, we are somewhat on this path. Russia is perhaps so involved in Syria because its oil is worth less and less and its economy is tanking. Not good for Putin.
Same with Saudi. They are feeling the pinch.

In an Op-Ed piece today, President Carter says, "...the United States and Russia must find ways to work beyond the lack of trust that undermined the previous cease-fire...."

Sadly for one's hopes for peace and a resolution to the ongoing horror, the fundamental problem is not merely lack of trust or conflicting desires for control of turf. That is true for some parties, but for others the basic goal is the destruction of their perceived enemies. Not everyone wants to stop the killing across the board.

If we want to truly understand the region and maintain any hope for contributing to a lessening of its violence, we must cease the tendency to view what goes on there through the lens of Western political, social, and moral values.

As to Western values, as the U.S. government has determined that it is, in fact, likely this was a Russian airstrike, it would be fair to ask Donald Trump at the first debate what his reaction is. And, for the moderator to be prepared with follow-up interrogatives if necessary.

Steve from Oakland,
Agreed. Ask Trump that question.

The US "mistakenly" killed 60 Syrian soldiers. Possibly an error. Possibly intentional. And either way the victims were part of a brutal military regime that is committing war crimes left and right.

The Russians "mistakenly" kill aid workers and civilians, and destroy tons of humanitarian aid. 99.9% intentional. And either way the victims were the best part of humanity, risking their lives to help others in need.

The left doesn't care, because the US military is involved. Both sides are bad.

The right doesn't care, because Putin is an effective leader. Neither side is bad.

So nothing changes.
Gee, Jon in New Mexico, you're implying that the country's best intelligence doesn't know about current trends in the presidential election? Seen any UFOs recently, Jon?

The only thing I know for sure is no one knows what to do regarding Syria.

A friend--a film maker--met what we called "insurgents" at the time in Canada in 2005. They were Iraqis that had allied themselves with Al Queda and other US enemies. My friend, with indignant fervor and anger, challenged these men to explain why they were fighting Americans. They didn't answer the question, but stated that my friend, and other American citizens, should be grateful for their efforts--their retreat action war with the US. This statement stopped my friend cold, because it made no sense.
Their explanation: If the insurgents had not slowed American hubris in Iraq, the war would have spread to an American invasion of Syria and Iran. And then they said, "The Middle East is a place for Superpowers to spend money, not to fight wars."
My friend said, "There is only one Superpower."
The insurgent said, "Well, if you insist on fighting in the Middle East, there will be NO Superpower."
My opinion...George Bush Sr is looking smarter every day. He knew when to stop.

Mike -- the problem is that "moderates" are in very short supply. Syria isn't Denmark, don't even think about that. It is a desperately factionalized nation that has descended to dog-eat-dog brutal religious/civil war -- a war that is multi-ethnic.

Nobody is going to win this. It is an everybody-loses contest. But some think that as long as they come out "on top," and their opponents are dead ... they won.

Most of the people fighting have gone far, far past any calculation, and are simply fighting out of blind hatred.

Death and exhaustion are the only end-points.
If he was listening then why did he make the comment in the first place?

Nate Cohn has outdone himself on this one. Excellent work.

He captured with a small, elegant test exactly what I’ve been explaining to family and friends for the entire election cycle so far – most poll results differ because of modeling/weighting rather than actual differences in responses. (Now I can just send them a link to this article instead of taking the time to explain it in my own words. Thanks.)

Beyond the issues that are inherent in modeling a voting population, there are variations introduced by the data gathering method (online vs. telephone, landline vs. cell), languages (English only vs. English/Spanish), potential social bias, and others issues.

I’m not even sure that averaging poll results is even valid, considering the herding tendency.

It's a tough year to follow and interpret poll results. Regardless of who wins, November 9th will be a very enjoyable and interesting day for wonks of all stripes.

Martin, circles. What a pleasant surprise. I love circles. They are round. They have no edges. They have radii and circumferences and areas, like the Pizza Pi I had for dinner tonight.

I have no idea what this puzzle is about. I have a vague feeling it is about the movie Top Gun. But I don't see Tom. I see Tim.

What really bothered me was the references to the Mets who are leading in the Wild Card. I want the Mets to go away and so, tonight, I am officially placing the John Bok Curse on them and from this date forawrd they will lose.

Sorry, Martin, the John Lek Curse was only for this game, 2-0 in favor of the Giants. BTW, who is that guy Romo? I thought he was on the Cowboys and injured. Why is he pitching in relief for the Giants?
Romo has only been a Giant.  He was our closer for a while.
Okay, can someone fill me in on the backstory to this particular curse?

I supect that the Horn and Hardarts automats (see below) qualify as the first "fast food" restaurants in the country. I vividly recall visting one often during the mid 1950's in Manhattan. You had to walk up and put money in a slot to get your prepared food of all kinds, so maybe the later arriving chains simply improved on the concept by adding drive throughs and menus.
Killing totalitarian forces in Syria now massacring innocent civilians equals bombing a humanitarian convey? Gee, Dreamer in Syracuse, your moral equivalency is breathtakingly revealing.

Amen. It's time for decapitation strikes against all of Syria's command and control infrastructure, including Assad and his cronies. Perhaps some Russian "advisors" will be accidentally killed as well in the confusion. It's past time Putin and Assad learned that they are not free to slaughter civilians with impunity.

Terry Neal, tell the Russians that. Unfortunately, they won't hear your altruistic message. But maybe if we appease the Russian all threats of war will magically go away, right, Terry in North Carolina?
It would be great if you could prove either one of those statements.
Mike -- We are NOT on the side of the Syrian government troops, rather the rebels trying to get rid of Assad. That being said, the bombing of Syrian troops WAS a mistake which US gov't admitted.
So, what was in the convoy that the UN isn't telling anyone about?

Right, the U.N. was shipping in a convoy of surface-to-air missiles or something.  Manny, if they were effective like that, this conflict would have been ended years ago by U.N. military interference.
That was proven to be a terrible error--this appears to be purposeful on the part of the Russians.
